image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives About this object

profileText: A Representative from Kentucky; born in Hardin County, Ky., November 1, 1829; completed preparatory studies; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1852 and commenced practice in Owensboro, Ky.; judge of Davis County in 1854; member of the State house of representatives in 1861; elected as a Unionist to the Thirty-seventh Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the death of James S. Jackson; reelected to the Thirty-eighth Congress and served from December 1, 1862, to March 3, 1865; unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1864 to the Thirty-ninth Congress; United States Minister to Denmark 1865-1870; resigned in 1870 and settled in New York City; lecturer on constitutional law at Columbia College; president of the Medico-Legal Society of New York; died in Jersey City, N.J., February 23, 1908; interment in Webb Memorial Chapel, Madison, N.J.

note.content: Elected to fill vacancy caused by death of James S. Jackson, and took his seat December 1, 1862.
Election unsuccessfully contested by John H. McHenry, Jr.

researchRecord.name: In the Charles Lanman Collection, 1792-1890, 1 cubic foot.
researchRecord.description: Persons represented include George Yeaman. An unpublished finding aid is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: 1865, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from George Helm Yeaman to James Speed written on July 3, 1865. In the letter, George Yeaman asks for a pardon for R. H. Baker, Jr., of Norfolk.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1883, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from George Helm Yeaman to President Arthur written on October 6, 1883. In the letter, George Yeaman recommends James Z. Moore for appointment as a territorial judge.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: In the Henry Charles Lea Papers, 1870, 10 items.
researchRecord.description: Correspondence with George Yeaman, 1870. Comprises items from Yeaman of the U. S. Legation in Copenhagen regarding Lea's access to materials in the Royal Library, with 1 item from librarian C. Bruun to Yeaman, and 1 item from Lea to Yeaman.
